title: Modeling - Logistic Diff Eq with Euler

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Liquid fertilizer is injected into a hydroponics growing system via a pumping system. The total amount of liquid fertilizer injected into the growing system by time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is modeled by the function <math alttext="uppercase F"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the logistic differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of uppercase F, with respect to t, equals one third times uppercase F times open parenthesis, 6 minus F, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in months and <math alttext="uppercase F"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in liters. At time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, 3 liters of liquid fertilizer are injected into the growing system. (Note: Hydroponics is the process of growing plants in sand, gravel, or liquid, with added nutrients but without soil.) (a) (i) Find <math alttext="the limit as t approaches infinity, of, uppercase F of t"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munder><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.(ii) Find <math alttext="the limit as t approaches infinity, of, the derivative of uppercase F, with respect to t"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Liquid fertilizer is injected into a hydroponics growing system via a pumping system. The total amount of liquid fertilizer injected into the growing system by time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is modeled by the function <math alttext="uppercase F"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the logistic differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of uppercase F, with respect to t, equals one third times uppercase F times open parenthesis, 6 minus F, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in months and <math alttext="uppercase F"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in liters. At time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, 3 liters of liquid fertilizer are injected into the growing system. (Note: Hydroponics is the process of growing plants in sand, gravel, or liquid, with added nutrients but without soil.) (a) (i) Find <math alttext="the limit as t approaches infinity, of, uppercase F of t"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munder><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.(ii) Find <math alttext="the limit as t approaches infinity, of, the derivative of uppercase F, with respect to t"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Find the value of <math alttext="the derivative of uppercase F, with respect to t"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> at the time when <math alttext="uppercase F"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is increasing most rapidly. Give a reason for your answer, and indicate units of measure.

(c) Find <math alttext="the second derivative of uppercase F, with respect to t"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> in terms of <math alttext="uppercase F"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) (i) Use Euler’s method, starting at <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> with two steps of equal size, to approximate the total amount of liquid fertilizer injected into the growing system by time <math alttext="t equals 1"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> month. Show the computations that lead to your answer.(ii) Is the approximation an overestimate or an underestimate for the total amount of liquid fertilizer injected into the growing system by time <math alttext="t equals 1"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> month? Give a reason for your answer.

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
